bioghist.p: Wilmington Whaling Company was organized pn November 23, 1833. In 1835 the company purchased the whaleship Ceres in New Bedford, and she became the pioneer of the fleet. The Ceres, sailed in April, 1835 and was absent two and a half years. Ceres (second voyage) sailed December 1, 1837, and absent forty months with profitable results. The Ceres made another unprofitable voyage afterwards. The whaling industry then declined, and the company sold its property in 1846 and went out of existence. Bernard Bradley was a teacher of mathematics at Riley's College. He made the voyage on the Ceres for his health.

scopecontent.p: Journal of Bernard Bradley, Wilmington Whaling Co., kept during his voyage aboard the Ceres in 1841-1843. Bradley describes life on board, stops in ports for provisioning, and the taking of whales. Later passages appear to be in another hand, possibly that of William Eakins. Some pages at the end of the volume were used as a writing exercise book.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
